result.execSummary:
The defendant Geoffrey B Oyler was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Defendant IS Eligible for Challenge Incarceration and Substance Abuse Programs.
May transfer probation to Milwaukee County

miscConds.notes: Cash bail applied to costs, paid in full. Balance refunded to poster.

Submit to an AODA assessment, follow through with any treatment, counseling.  No use or possession of alcohol or illegal drugs/drug paraphernalia. Comply with random urine screens.  Maintain absolute sobriety. No use or possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription. Valid prescriptions only with prior agent approval and to be taken only in the manner they are ordered. Sign releases for agent.

Attend a minimum of 1 Self-Help meeting per week. Disclose this case to any treating physician. Maintain employment and/or school combination. Provide DNA Specimen unless previously obtained. Surcharge is imposed. Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by agent. 
  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.

timeConds.notes: Straight Time - Commencing forthwith.  LAST 90 days are STAYED for use at agent's discretion. May transfer to Milwaukee County.

records.addlTxt: Notice of Case Status Change - Revoked - Sentenced to Prison

The Defendant is granted a release from the jail from 8:00 am to 8:00 pm on February 28, 2016 to attend a service related to the death of his father. Defendant is to be tested for alcohol and drugs (10 panel drug test if available) upon his return. Any non-negative results to be forwarded to Branch 4 staff. Signed by Judge Carter on 02/16/16.
letter from Attorney Anthony Cotton requesting that Defendant be allowed 12 hour furlough on 2/28/16 to attend father's memorial celebration.
Wisconsin Community Service non-compliance letter received and filed.
with Elements of criminal offenses to which plea is being entered.

Defendant Geoffrey B Oyler in court with Attorney Anthony D Cotton.   District Attorney's Office Law Intern Kelly Pingel appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court quashes warrant.  Defendant enters a guilty plea to Count #1.  Court performs plea colloquy and finds Defendant guilty of Count #1.  Count #2 is dismissed and read-in.  State gives sentencing recommendations.  Attorney Cotton makes statements regarding sentencing.  Defendant makes statements.  Court sentences the Defendant to the following:

COUNT #1:  IMPOSED AND STAYED SENTENCE OF:   

3 YEARS IMPRISONMENT (CREDIT - _ days)
  -  18 MONTHS OF INITIAL CONFINEMENT
  -  18 MONTHS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISON 

TERM OF PROBATION:  3 YEARS    **Transfer allowed to Milwaukee County** 

CONDITIONS OF PROBATON:  
____AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended;
____Absolute Sobriety;  Random U.A.'s ; 
____No Use or Possession of alcohol or illegal drugs 
____No Use or Possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription;
____Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are 
prescribed/;sign releases.
____Disclose this case to any treating physician
____Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;
____Maintain employment and/or combination of schooling 
____Attend a minimum of 1 self-help meeting per week
____DNA sample to be provided if not yet previously done 

COSTS:  $268.00 & $250.00 DNA surcharge (to be paid out of cash bail posted and remainder to be returned to poster)

CONDITION TIME:  150 Days (Straight time) - LAST 90 DAYS STAYED (to be used at agent's discretion), to commence forthwith - Defendant taken into custody   **Transfer allowed to Milwaukee County**

Defendant is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program.
Defendant is eligible for the Substance Abuse Program. 

Felony warnings, voting rights and firearms warnings given.

Defendant Geoffrey B Oyler in court with Attorney Anthony D Cotton.  Mary C. Brejcha appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Case called for motion hearing.  Defense moves for sequestration of witnesses.  Court grants request.  Trooper David Schmidt is sworn-in and testifies.  Cross-examination by Attorney Cotton.  Re-direct by the state.  Correctional Officer Elizabeth Torn is sworn-in and testifies.  Cross-examination by Attorney Cotton.  State rests.  No testimony by the defense.  State gives closing statements.  Closing statements by Attorney Cotton.  Court denies motion for reasons stated on the record.  Attorney Cotton requests an adjourned date for further proceedings.   Court sets case for jury status and jury trial.  Bail remains as fixed.
Wisconsin Community Service non-compliance letter received and filed.

MODIFIED CONDITION:  Defandant must inform and treating physician of pending charges for possession of narcotics prior to receiving any prescriptions.
